title: Alfred Kästner
text:
Alfred Kästner (12 December 1882 – 12 April 1945) was a German <a href="communist">communist</a> and <a href="German%20resistance%20to%20Nazism">resistance fighter</a> against <a href="Nazism">Nazism</a>.
Biography.
Kästner was born in <a href="Leipzig">Leipzig</a>. He was a wood merchant by profession, and a member of the <a href="Spartacus%20League">Spartacus League</a>. In November 1918, during the <a href="German%20Revolution">German Revolution</a>, he was elected to the Leipzig <a href="Workers%27%20council">Workers' and Soldiers' Council</a>. Kästner was also a founding member of the Leipzig branch of the <a href="Communist%20Party%20of%20Germany">Communist Party of Germany</a> (KPD) in 1919. When the KPD was banned in 1923–1924, underground meetings were held in Kästner's office.
After the <a href="Nazi%20Party">Nazi Party</a> came to power in 1933, Kästner's office was once again used for underground gatherings of KPD activists from Leipzig as well as nearby towns such as <a href="Chemnitz">Chemnitz</a>, <a href="Dresden">Dresden</a> and <a href="Riesa">Riesa</a>, and for printing illegal pamphlets.
Kästner was arrested in September 1933; although he was sentenced to two years and eight months' imprisonment, he was interned in the concentration camps <a href="Sachsenburg%20concentration%20camp">Sachsenburg</a>, <a href="Sachsenhausen%20concentration%20camp">Sachsenhausen</a> and <a href="Buchenwald%20concentration%20camp">Buchenwald</a> until 1939.
After his release, Kästner joined the resistance group around <a href="Georg%20Schumann%20%28resistance%20fighter%29">Georg Schumann</a> and maintained contact with resistance fighters in <a href="Hamburg">Hamburg</a>, <a href="Bavaria">Bavaria</a> and <a href="W%C3%BCrttemberg">Württemberg</a>.
Kästner was arrested again by the <a href="Gestapo">Gestapo</a> on 11 March 1945. He was shot to death by the <a href="SS">SS</a> in , northwest of Leipzig, and thrown in a pit together with 52 other German and foreign anti-fascists on 12 April 1945, just a week before the <a href="U.S.%20Army">U.S. Army</a> entered Leipzig.
The street in the Südvorstadt borough of Leipzig where Alfred Kästner lived was renamed Alfred-Kästner-Straße on 1 August 1945.
